												This game is good.This game is good!This game is good?Yep. Saviors, the 19 cent 2D shootemup, is good. I was not expecting this. No really, I was looking forward to tearing this game to pieces. Unfortunately for me, the only worthy complaint is the terrible character-models and bland art-direction. Once I actually played the game, it all came together quite nicely. This is a legitimately decent indie shooter.Humanity is doomed AGAIN, or maybe they're not doomed, or maybe I don't care. This threadbare and easily ignorable plot sets up 15 stages of shooting action. For an arcade 2D shooter, that's quite a lot. Thankfully, these stages are well-paced, with only 5 of them having real boss-fights. Furthermore, your first experience with this game is liable to be the story mode, where the large number of stages seems a bit more sensible.In story mode, you're given the choice of three pilots, each with their own ship. As you play through the stages, you'll gather experience, which leads to level-up perks. Also, in-between stages you can decide on primary, secondary, and side weapons. There's an interesting amount of strategy, that's tempered by good old-fashioned reflexes. The better you do, the higher your score, which also ties into your experience. The level of difficulty can also be changed, just in case things get too easy or too difficult. The other modes remove the stage to stage decision-making. Instead you're given a choice between various ships and weapon-systems. All you have to do is select the setup that suits your play-style.With Saviors, unlike most shooters, you always have an idea of what's approaching. There are constant indicators for every enemy ship, so you can focus on either destroying them immediately, or let them stay on-screen for a bit, so you can maintain your chain combo. Each ship has their own arsenal and pattern. As you progress you'll face newer ships in greater numbers. Another aspect that is unlike most shooters is the fact that you get a shield. Obviously it's not something to be relied upon, but it comes in handy for those stray shots. The boss-fights tend to be bullet-hell affairs. All you really have to do is hang back, fire away, and dodge for seemingly an eternity. For most players, the normal difficulty provides a sufficient challenge.Saviors has a good "flow" to it. There are new dangers or problems to deal with in every stage, but nothing too absurd that it changes the nature of the game. The mechanics are also fairly solid, none of the damage you'll take will feel cheap. Although, sometimes the game can get a little too busy with the explosions. On the bright side, this tends to happen during "break" mode, where enemies and their projectiles explode frequently. It's very satisfying, though sometimes tough to control.As far as other complaints go, I think bosses tend to take a little too long. Their last sliver of energy takes forever to drain away, even if I unload all of my limited secondary weapons on it. Each ship also has their own speed setting. While it's nice to have a faster ship for reaching enemies quickly; more often than not, I'd rather have slow-movement for those waves of bullets I need to dodge. Otherwise it's mostly nitpicks, like some perks not being very useful.Saviors is a very nice surprise. It has solid mechanics, a decent amount of variety, enough replay-value to last, and it will likely cost you a penny or two after selling the cards. It just might be worth your time.

About Star SaviorsInspired by Ikaruga, Raiden, and Radiant Silvergun, Saviors brings the best bullet hell experience you can find on Steam. Play through 18 challenging stages in this ultimate test of tactics and reflexes. The Graphics  	Buller hell games really don't need that much graphic power, with using simple meshes (like this game does) it works perfectly. But this just can't be overlooked, the character models are taken out of a nightmare, and just put in there to haunt you for the rest of your life. If you can just pass this simple detail, everything else is fine. The Music	Empowering, just the music it needs for the type of game it is. Mostly heard is metal, with a few dubstep sounds mixed within. If you love that kind of music, you are going to love this game.  The Story 	You as the reader, have probably heard this story over and over again, the story where you are the chosen one and you have to save the world. Now this may come as a suprise, but this game actually changes it (no it doesn't). You follow a relatively average campaign through the galaxy to prevent a war that is going to unfold at any moment. Also the game tells you multiple times that you are the chosen one, and that you are the only one who can do what you are doing. Although at the start of the campaing, you are given the choice between 3 characters, and while you are doing what you are doing, the other 2 characters are doing the same, but remember how you are the only one capable of doing this ? Well you are not. The Gameplay  Really fast paced, you don't have time to think about what you are going to do, as you are bombarded all the time. It does get progressively harder with every level, as it is expected. The bosses man were they hard, mostly that one at the 13'th level, but nothing a second (if only it were 2 tries) attempt couldn't fix. All in All  Star Saviors	 is a very nice Action Game!9/10 From MeSweep

												Bought this at a good discount, just for the cards to be honest.Started playing, just to see what type of game it was and ... finished it in one go. Now, my game library is filled with "hey, this is a pretty good game, let's put it aside for later" stuff, which I tend not to ever start up again. So saying that I finished a game in one setting is pretty exceptional in itself.Basically it is a fairly standard shoot 'm up with bullet-hell bosses. Normally I despise bullet-hells, but here it was not so bad at all. Consider it a bullet-hell-light if you want.You get the typical top-down view most of the time, with occasionally switched camera perspectives. We've seen it all countless times in these sort of games but it continues to impress.Grapically the game is underwhelming. The "3D" avatars that brief you in between missions are of a quality you would expect from games of 1996, the ships lack animation and the UI is fairly boring. Still, the ship design is pretty good from a Sci-Fi point of view and, while boring and uninspired, the UI offers exactly what you want from it, without distracting. The 3D backgrounds are nice as well although don't expect Crysis-levels of backdrops for this price.Speaking about the briefings, the story is forgettable as well. The Earth is once again in danger yadda yadda yadda. But who cares about a story in this type of game anyway?The sound is meh. The fighting sounds OK but not more than that. The soundtrack is pretty good, FAR better than you would would expect from such a cheap game. Too bad there are only 3 or so tracks.The gameplay on the other hand is outstanding. Shooting just feels great. There is also plenty of choice in weaponry and it is a joy to combine the different weapon types to build your own little ship of doom (trademark pending). The levels are also short and vary in background, so you really are driven to see what comes next. The "one more turn" is strong with this one!The developers included a very sweet "break" scoring mechanic, that awards a high score multiplier with mass-explosions, replacing the screen-wiping bomb you usually get in SHMUPS with chain-reactions of fire and death. This is an excellent choice and seeing screen after screen of enemies explode is soooo rewarding, you will want to drive up your multiplier even if you don't care about highscores at all.There is also a level-up system, awarding good scores even more. The unlockable perks are not extra-ordinary, but do allow you to customise your ship to your liking. There are five attributes to build up and I went full defence for example, while other peeps will want to go full offence. Similarly, you can choose from between 3 different ships at the start.You can finish the game in about 90 minutes, which was just good enough. Any longer might have been too repetitive.Summarizing: this is a hidden gem for such a low price. Whether you are new to shoot-em-ups or like the genre, you can't really do bad with this purchase.Score:Gameplay: 8/10Graphics: 5/10Sound: 6/10Difficulty: 6/10Value-for-money: 9/10

												It's a great value for the price. Saviors delivers a satisfying shoot em up experience. It's definitely challenging, playing it on normal was kicking my butt. I was never able to handle the higher difficulties. If you're looking for a bullet hell type experience you'll definitely find one here. The game play is solid. The main feature of the game is comboing your kills to the point where you cause massive chain explosions of all ships on the screen. It's quite a satisfying mechanic. Watching wave upon wave of enemy ships melt while you're under a break chain was very fulfilling. The game shows the sillouette of every approaching enemy so you can plan where to move your ship before enemies appear. It's a nice feature that definitely makes up for how hard it gets. There's 18 levels in the game, with multiple game modes, but it does get repetitive after you've played through a couple times. The game is cheap though, and the value you get out of it is well worth it. The music for the game is fantastic, I particularly liked the boss fight music. The NPC character heads are hideous and worth the price alone just to experience.

But, boy, was that to change! The music and the way the game moves, really makes this game. It's a pity the rest of the graphics is a bit lacking: The enemies are a bit dull. Yes, they are huge, but very little details and variations. And the backdrop could also have been a little bit more interesting. But the graphic mechanics, if I can call it that, is very good. You feel you drive your plane in all directions while playing this bullet hell of a game.Did I mention the music? It's been a long while since I've heard this level of energic music, which actually fits the game. It's really the best you can get from a game music.As for gameplay, it's pretty standard. Easy mode should be avoided, unless your try to play through the "campaign". The fun starts at Hard. You also have different modes. The campaign let's you modify your plane for each level, and level up perks, while the other modes is fairly standard: Choose a loadout and see how far you can go with what you've got.So will this game be played more in the future? For sure! It's a game that I will pull out when I feel I just need to shoot something. Or perhaps challenge a friend. It hasn't got too much diversity in levels, so it isn't a game I will play for hours and hours.Finally, is it worth my money and time? Fer sure! It could have been sold for even more than the current price, and still be worth a purchase. It's not the most unique shoot'em up, but it deserves to be in the collection of any fan of the genre.I really wish they make a sequel with the same quality of music and even better graphics. Then it will be a real hit!

The music is nice and up beat and suitably odd/unique and fits well with the gameplay.Graphics are very good but nothing that's going to rock your socks, nor should you expect that from <$2.00Good mash up of enemies and a nice rhythm with some cool boss fights with your typcial "learn the firing patterns" gameplay.There is a story. 												The game description invokes some big names, but let's establish one thing right away: This is not a game that follows in the footsteps of games like Ikaruga or Radiant Silvergun; the production values on display and certain design decisions keep Star Saviors from that epic tier level of shmups. Fortunately, Star Saviors has a lot of things going for it that make it absolutely worth playing, particularly if you're new or not so skilled at shmup/bullet hell games.A major talking point is the price. It's very low for a game with as much content and competence on display here, and in a way I almost feel like the price sends a message that the game is crappier than it is. However, there's a very noticable low-poly almost amateur level to the character models and story presentation, but in a shmup game this isn't of importance and it's bizarre how much the story is pushed by the developers considering their study of the "shmup greats".But enough of all that, you say, how does it play? For a one dollar game, pretty damn well. I jacked it up to 1440p and blazed ahead at 120 fps, with smooth movement and easy dodging using a Dualshock 4. Games like Ikaruga have a certain elegance to the way the enemies approach and attack you, and in many ways a perfect run of a shmup like that is a beautifully coreographed dance between the player and the AI. In Star Saviors' case many enemies just come at you without an identifiable pattern, but it's clear a lot of throught and time was put into making sure that it felt good to shoot the enemies and to have bullet patterns that are always dodgable.As a veteran of this genre, I thought the game was quite easy at first. The ships have a shield that can take a hit before you start losing "hull damage", meaning that you can fail to dodge quite a bit before losing a life. If you are a veteran, however, Star Saviors has multiple difficulty modes and customizations to tailor the experience to you. To be clear: You can approach this game at any skill level with the genre and have a good time, with veterans missing some more advanced systems and newbies able to ease themselves into the genre using this game without being overwhelmed at the start.Ikaruga has a brilliant chaining system with the color changing, Radiant Silvergun had a massive variety of attacks on one ship as well as chaining based on the colors of the enemies. Sine Mora has a beautiful presentation of it's story and art design. Star Saviors does not meet any of the lofty levels of these greats, but the price is an unaviodable factor that makes it much easier to accept the things it does do right. If you love this genre and play it to death, a buck towards these devs might help to allow them to continue refining their craft and maybe realize their dream of releasing an epic-tier shmup. You'll have a good time regardless on the higher levels, and the RPG-like ship customizations after each story level offers a nice change of pace. If anyone has made it this far and has an interest in the genre, but might feel intimidated by the often high level of difficulty and skill required - this is absolutely your excellent starting point and the price couldn't be easier to swallow to see if these kind of games can be for you. If it turns out that they are, do realize that there's a next level and proceed to move on to more pricey but higher quality titles like Astebreed, Ikaruga, Radiant Silvergun, and any game made by Cave.Star Saviors may not reach the high goals set by the titles it aspires to, but it's amazing that a $1 title can even make an honest attempt at that level. I recommend it to anyone who's curious or even anyone who enjoys arcade space shooters. I'd say the amount of words and time I've spent even talking about a game at this price level should say a lot.

												The game's mechanics are terrible. The enemies simply use your keyboard input as a targeting mechanic, the result being similar to the simple plastic mechanical games that you used to find at dollar stores. I was a huge fan of Galaga. I played it wherever I could find it. My friends always knew when I was younger that, if I went missing, to just look for the closest Galaga game. I love the format, but this doesn't do it justice.Beyond that, I found the dialog irritating. The author seemed to think they were being witty, or tongue-and-cheek, but it just came across as childish and ignorant. What the teacher says during the tutorial, for instance, stands behind the premise that you have somehow forgotten what you're doing and constantly surfaces how silly it is. The author is trying to say that tutorials are silly in the first-place, as your character should already know what they're doing. Of course, a tutorial is always needed when undertaking a new task. Why would we assume our character isn't just learning how to fly a ship? Why would we imply that they already know how to fly one, but have just forgotten for some reason?Sorry, I just had to rant. It's a top-down shooter; you could care less about the dialog. So, then, in conclusion: This game is a horrible example of the format with nothing to elevate it beyond others in its genre and isn't worth the 19 cents I paid for it. I've uninstalled it and can safely say that not even the most boring of Saturday afternoons can make me second-guess that decision.

Saviors doesn't mince words or waste time. It throws you right into the heart of a laser-heavy space battle and lets somebody else do the explaining. In honor of that, I will try to be brief.Saviors is a "gamer's game." It is fully aware that it is a game, and seems to be fine if you are, too. Immersion is only one path to greatness as a video game product, and this game shows that you don't need to re-invent the wheel if you've got a really good wheel.The gameplay is incredibly smooth. Three buttons and arrows, and go get 'em, tiger. I had never heard the slang term "bullet hell" for the scrolling shooter genre, but it took about twenty-five seconds to make perfect sense. Saviors nails a very difficult design concept: the controls should fit like a glove, but that doesn't mean that every task should be intuitive. A few formations will make you think twice or leave you guessing, but unlike so many games that use unpredictability and no-win situations to cheaply raise difficulty, you can always hunker down in Saviors and juice a little more playtime out of sheer instinct.My big complaint - and the reason that I don't recommend it for everybody, everywhere, is that its presentation is that of several very good parts that don't make a cohesive whole. I have to admit that I do favor the ability to immerse myself in a game world, and each of the elements here don't quite go together. The sprites and particles have different reflective properties, and neither quite look like they are a part of the world painted by the backgrounds. The soundtrack is vivid and pulse-pounding, but it sounds like it was for a completely different game and overpowers the sound effects by default. For this style of game, I get that many gamers mute the game audio and throw on their own esoteric techno or speed-metal soundtracks, but as a casual gamer, I like to see the little touches that give me more than a series of well-designed levels: they give me a world to play through.Saviors gets truly difficult, but it definitely starts off at an inviting level, so people new to the genre (like me) can work their way in. At all levels, though, it gets perhaps the most important part of this genre right: you will have one or two moments per level where you ask yourself, "How on earth did I get myself out of that one?" It's intense and addictive. This is a superbly-designed game at a very attractive price. If you like space shooters at all, or want to find out if you do, buy right away.

Saviors doesn't mince words or waste time. It throws you right into the heart of a laser-heavy space battle and lets somebody else do the explaining. In honor of that, I will try to be brief.Saviors is a "gamer's game." It is fully aware that it is a game, and seems to be fine if you are, too. Immersion is only one path to greatness as a video game product, and this game shows that you don't need to re-invent the wheel if you've got a really good wheel.The gameplay is incredibly smooth. Three buttons and arrows, and go get 'em, tiger. I had never heard the slang term "bullet hell" for the scrolling shooter genre, but it took about twenty-five seconds to make perfect sense. Saviors nails a very difficult design concept: the controls should fit like a glove, but that doesn't mean that every task should be intuitive. A few formations will make you think twice or leave you guessing, but unlike so many games that use unpredictability and no-win situations to cheaply raise difficulty, you can always hunker down in Saviors and juice a little more playtime out of sheer instinct.My big complaint - and the reason that I don't recommend it for everybody, everywhere, is that its presentation is that of several very good parts that don't make a cohesive whole. I have to admit that I do favor the ability to immerse myself in a game world, and each of the elements here don't quite go together. The sprites and particles have different reflective properties, and neither quite look like they are a part of the world painted by the backgrounds. The soundtrack is vivid and pulse-pounding, but it sounds like it was for a completely different game and overpowers the sound effects by default. For this style of game, I get that many gamers mute the game audio and throw on their own esoteric techno or speed-metal soundtracks, but as a casual gamer, I like to see the little touches that give me more than a series of well-designed levels: they give me a world to play through.Saviors gets truly difficult, but it definitely starts off at an inviting level, so people new to the genre (like me) can work their way in. At all levels, though, it gets perhaps the most important part of this genre right: you will have one or two moments per level where you ask yourself, "How on earth did I get myself out of that one?" It's intense and addictive. This is a superbly-designed game at a very attractive price. If you like space shooters at all, or want to find out if you do, buy right away.

Saviors is an excellent shoot 'em up whose strong points are the shield system, the huge variety of weapons, plenty of different enemies and game modes and an unusually large amount of stages for the genre.Let's talk about these in more detail.So you never played a shoot 'em up before, or you are not good at all in those games, but there's something fun about dodging bullets and firing away your laser spreads at hundreds of incoming enemies. Well, here's your game. Two game aspects will make the ride nice for the casual shooters or players that hate ultra high difficulty. The first one is the shield system. In Saviors, you effectively have two health bars: your shield and your ship's armor. You don't immediately die after being hit once, instead, your shield takes the damage, and different enemy bullets do different damage. Once your shield is depleted entirely, any damage goes directly to your ship. But, unlike your ship's armor, if you can stay out of harm's way for long enough, your shield will recover. It can even fully recover. This means one bullet doesn't mean the end and it can actually ease the new players into the bullet hell basics of dodging, making them better at the genre. The second aspect of the game that welcomes the new players is, of course, the many different difficulties.On the topic of offense, Saviors has it's own merits as well. Your ship will use three weapons at once at all times: main weapon, secondary weapon and missiles. Your shooting button will fire two weapons at the same time: the main shot and the secondary shot. Another button is assigned for missile launch. You can also choose between two attack modes at any time. The standard attack mode will fire both main and secondary weapons forward. The alternative mode enables your ship to fire the secondary weapon sideways while still firing the main gun forward. There's a vast number of weapons you can choose from in the game. In story mode, you unlock new weapons as you progress. There's an arcade mode where you can choose among many different preset types. Each different weapon will have it's own strengths and weaknesses. Some weapons will cover a lot of space with a large spread. Others will have narrow spread but high damage. Others will fire in bursts of high damage. Others will have weaker, continuous fire that deals better damage over time. Others yet work like shotguns.The story mode is unusually lengthy. The shoot 'em up genre will generally offer you about 5 stages and that's it. Saviors offers 18 stages. Slightly smaller stages combine with the death system to make progression smooth. Every time you die you have to start the stage over, but since they are not immense stages, it will give you better sense of progression and success than infinite continues.The music has a rather strange choice of synths mixed with rocking guitar on fast electronic beats. It feels weird at times and exciting at others. And there are other times too when it's weird and exciting at the same time when the strange synths work at some great tunes. Exciting blood pumping OST is what every shooter should have and Saviors delivers in a unique way that will have you consider buying the OST.The poor aspects of the game are outweighed by the good ones by a far margin. Nevertheless Poor character designs, personalities and dialogs will make you skip the story every time. The art is kinda ugly all around as well (menus, backgrounds, "hud" etc). It doesn't wreak the fun, but it certainly doesn't help.Finally, the price is perfectly fair even at full. The game could actually be more expensive.Highly recommended.

												Got this game in a bundle and I'm liking it. A rendition of the classic shoot-em-up game in space as you fly a plane filled with unlimited ammo, but a limited quantity of secondary weapon (special). I've played a few in the 90s and while the graphics for savior during gameplay is above average, all the other graphics are below average. The pilots are just creepy-looking, especially when you want to read the text for the story, but you have to also stare at the images to do so. During gameplay, I stuck with easy-mode at first and the game can be completed without much skill (just need to follow the game prediction of where the enemies will come and you'll be fine). Increasing the level definitely is where the fun comes in as you get more things to shoot at to maintain your burst gauge. Also, the game is still enjoyable where you can still keep track of everything you need to dodge, while keeping track of your plane during gameplay (which can be hard as some games do a poor job at this). The perks aren't at first very clear on how they can help you, but I find the first two perks being the most valuable as they increase damage, rate speed, and spread. A large variety of weaponry for you to choose from and some levels definitely benefit from you choosing the right combination of weapon. For example, one level was a boss battle where the boss is predominantly in front of you. So I chose the weapons that state high damage + focused on shooting in front of me only. Cleared the level much quicker than choosing the weapons that spread out more + do less damage.Overall, the game is decent and has value in its gameplay for one to enjoy. Will have to try the co-op one day to see how that fares. However, enjoyable game to come back to every once in a while. 7/10.
